title: How many total cases of COVID-19 will the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) report for Canada as of 31 December 2020?
possible_answers: More than 342,646 but fewer than 428,308 cases
preds: 423k+ on 12/7, only need just over 200 new cases per day to break 428,308. Seems inevitable.
At 423k as of 12/8 and still increasing.
Canada added 135k cases in November, likely to add at least as many in December given acceleration of spread and upcoming Christmas travel. Total case number was 370k on Nov 29.

Since Nov. 23, the number has risen about 5,900 per day, which would equate to about 555,570 cases by the end of the year. Even if that's off by over 100,000 cases, it'd still surpass 428,303. I think the testing around the holidays will inflate the number as well.

389,775 as of December 2, an increase of 24,965 in 4 days, or 6241.25 per day. Another 38,533 cases takes us to Bin D. At straight line rate of growth, we cross that threshold in 6-7 days. Given exponential rate of growth, we'll probably cross over in 4-5 days, or December 7-8.

At the current rate the daily average would need to be between 1500-1600 for the next 30 days. Alberta had more cases than that yesterday so it is not likely to average to that low, so it is highly unlikely that we will get less than 428,308 cases especially without any major reduction strategies in place.
Would have to average less than 1672 cases to hit below the 4th bucket so basically impossible at this point.
11/30 - 378k cases with an average approaching 6k new per day... I don't see how the rate gets under 2k a day before the end of the year - Should exceed 428k in less than 2 weeks.
As of Nov 30 --378K...trend line doesnt look pretty

There are currently 370K confirmed cases with a monthly case growth rate of 60%+.  In order to drop below 428K, the rate would have to immediately drop to near 15% or scale down to near zero, which seems highly unlikely.  Earlier in the year it took almost 20 days to get the case growth rate to decline by 45 pct points
As of Nov 30th, there is already 370,000 cases. It's very likely that in the next month another 50k cases could be added.

364,810 cases on November 28, which represents 5746 new cases over day before. There are 33 reporting days left. Straight line projection by December 31 would be 189,618 additional cases, or a total of 554,428 at the end of the year.   Of course, the better projection should be exponential, not straight line. The Trudeau Administration said they expect a four-fold increase in new daily cases by year's end at present levels of social distancing--which seems hard to maintain with Christmas coming (https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-canada/update-1-canada-covid-19-daily-cases-could-soar-by-end-2020-say-medical-officials-in-grim-forecast-idUSL1N2I6142). The  IHME also predicts increasing new daily infections (https://covid19.healthdata.org/canada?view=infections-testing&tab=trend&test=infections).  Either way, 428,308 will likely be surpassed before December 10.

As of today the average daily increase needs to be around 2000 to reach below 428,000.
We currently are seeing 4 provinces with either close to or more than 1000 daily cases. It seems unlikely that we will go from 5000 to an average 2000 daily new cases.
Pushing 350 000 with peaks increasing in much of Canada... a doubling in under 2 months. 20% in another month seems likely/achievable

If we assume pandemic started around March, Canada has averaged 24K cases per month between march and Oct.  Carrying that trend forward through December would an additional 48K.  That would indicate roughly 225K total cases.  As 256K (the lowest threshold to be predicted) is well above 225K, I've placed a high likelihood Canada will fall below.  the US is seeing a significant increase (3rd wave) currently, but Canada has been more organized and appear better equipped to slow the spread.  As such, even with a significant surge it seems unlikely they will be above 256K.

From Nov 23 to Nov 24, cases went up 7052/day. (I may have gotten that number wrong.) There are 37 days from Wed Nov 25 through dec 31 times. At the rate of 7052/day, you get a total of 598,259 (337,335 as of Nov 24 + 260,924 (7052/day from Nov 24 through end of Dec). Looking at the growth rate of Covid from March to June, there was exponential growth. In the winter, people will likely hold more indoor events, so I think it's likely that we will see similar growth. That said, it is possible that people are learning from past mistakes and are using more masks. On balance, I think it's more likely that cases will increase. One important consideration: Canadian Thanksgiving already happened, so we may have already seen the biggest increase in Canada.
Current growth rate is increasing and would push well beyond 428k by 31 December even if it stabilizes.
Looks good night nurse at moment. Countries that resisted first wave well are vulnerable for quick-growth 2nd wave.

Current daily rate is north of 5k and Canada would need to average about 1/2 of that for the rest of the year to keep under that 428.3K bucket. Several metrics indicate that Canada is unlikely to turn this around enough to fall below 428.3k before 12/31 - 
* Canada's positive test rate is the highest it's been since May (when less than half as many people were being tested)
* Using PHAC's "longer range forecast" (slide 13 here https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/documents/services/diseases-maladies/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/epidemiological-economic-research-data/update-covid-19-canada-epidemiology-modelling-20201120-eng.pdf ) the daily rate would not be low enough even by the most optimistic end of the confidence band for the "essential activities only" forecast I think the probablility of seeing cases below the 428k range is closer to 0.25-0.5% than 1%, but I'm quite averse to having a 0 where something is still arguably possible.

Looks like bin 4 is inevitable. Corona fatigue is setting in, people are eager to socialize and shop in the holiday season. 
Difficult to understand shifting priorities of human behavior.
2,800 cases per day to reach highest bucket. Current rate is ~5,000. Holidays will exacerbate.

~330k cases today and 38 days to the end of the year, means ~2600 new cases per day to reach bucket 4. Given the virus is infectious enough that we can't rely on people to do the right thing to stop it's spread (not out of malicious  intent, it's just too hard), as Canada isn't entering a full lockdown I believe we will see a tapering from the current daily counts of ~4500-5000 new cases per day, not a sudden drop off in cases.  If we assume the reduction in daily cases is linear, Canada needs to come down to ~200 cases per day by the end of the year to avoid bucket 4.

At 320k today... assuming an aggregate of 4k new cases per day through the EOY is +/-480k. Even if the aggregate drops to 3k a day, the total would be 440k. I don't think we have seen the peak yet and even with lockdowns, you will still see a lag. Increased testing now versus March/April will also yield higher numbers. To get under 428k,  you would need to see <2.5k cases per day aggregate through the end of the year, which is unlikely.

PHAC modelling indicates >428,308 cases by the end of the year. Current cases: 320,719
Delta to 428,308: 107,589
Days to 2020-Dec-31: 40
Cases/day to hit 428,308: ~2,690
Cases reported today: 4,642 The "best" case given by PHAC shows CAN peaking at ~6k - 7k cases/day before reducing to ~4k - 6k/day (eye-balling the chart below). CAN will be well above 2.6k cases/day for the foreseeable future, so I think it'll practically take a miracle to avoid 428k cumulative cases. PHAC and many provincial govt's have just announced significant restrictions, but the next two weeks are "baked in". Some very rough calculations: 14 days at current rate: 4.6k * 14 + 320k ~ 385k cumulative cases.
Next 14 days at 1/2 the current rate ~ 417k.
Finally, another 12 days at 1/4 the current  rate ~ 431k
Total days: 40 -- just in time for new year's eve :-( This is my own back-of-the envelope to double-check my reading of PHAC's model. https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/documents/services/diseases-maladies/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/epidemiological-economic-research-data/update-covid-19-canada-epidemiology-modelling-20201120-eng.pdf
https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.04.17.20070086v1
Estimate 160000 cases by 31st. 2 states have locked down. I will adjust if more territories
even w/ full lockdown on 11/21 would require epic roll-off of new cases in 30 days to pull under 428k.
Cases are increasing in Canada likely to peak in December

As of November 19, Canada had 315,751 cases with 4,643 new cases and it showing a very slight down tick in the rate of increase. Assuming 4,000 new cases per day for the next 41 days gives us 164,000 more cases taking Canada to a total of 479,751 cases.
I imagine that Canada's case load is along the same trajectory as our own, but since it is such a sparsely populated tundra I weighted the lower tier options slightly heavier
6k cases a day currently, already at 316k cases.  so 6k times roughly 40 days = 556k cases.
All it takes is 25 more days at the current level (~4700 cases) and it enters the last bucket. And it still could get higher, so I think the odds of landing in the third bucket look very low.
Still not at the peak nearly three weeks later. As from Oct 28th - we could get to 460K.
Current case count is ~282k,  with more than a month to go and the speed of infection, it's likely to surpass 428k.

This spike is much worse than the prior. Assume holidays and quarantine fatigue will increase rates as well. Assuming spike continues for another twenty days, then decreases through December, average daily cases is ~3,500.
Current: 276K
Expected: 50 days x 3,500 = 175,000 Total: 451K

3 scenarios: ~33%: Peak and drop: At the lower end of the spectrum. Upping my estimate here to about 273 + 80. = 350k ~33%: Continue as-is: If the current trend continues we'll be at about 370k-ish ~33%: Keep accelerating: This scenario could see numbers >450k
@Ryan-Beck offers a clear analysis as to why I should move higher.
If we assume that Cda has hit the near maximum daily cases on the curve at this point then fewer than 428,308 is possible. I suspect we haven't hit that point just yet.

51 days remain, they'd have to average 1450 over the remaining days to hit the second bucket and an average of 3129 to hit the third bucket. Currently at about 4000 a day and still growing. I expected them to be peaking around now or sooner, but still no sign of a peak. Cases are blowing up like crazy in many countries. I have no idea why that is, so I'm pretty uncertain on forecasting it. Canada is still doing better than the US per million people, but if we assume the US is the high end of the range there's still a lot of room for cases in Canada to grow. At this point I'm switching to the highest bucket as most likely. Even if a peak is hit, levels remain around peak for a few weeks. It's looking unlikely that things will drop back down fast enough to stay below the highest bucket. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&hideControls=true&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=location&pickerSort=asc

251,338 as of 11/5 2020 with about 54 days to go.
10/7 total cases = 173,123 which equals 78215 in 29 days. Which equals 2,697 a day over those 29 days.
Extrapolating at that rate for 54 days = 145,641 additional cases for a total of 396,979 cases.
Over 250k - much faster than I expected. And with record/near record cases in most states. Haven’t (yet) enacted Euro style lockdowns - a bit looser. Oh Canada!

PHAC's figures tend to be consistently non-consistent since end-October, the daily new cases do not fit the actual difference between the total cases number and total cases of the previous day. On their page, they do not announce a respective amendment or revision. The number is recently jumping up higher than indicated by the daily count for no reason.
"Revisions" tend to be upwards, which make it appear more likely that Canada will leave the ""decrease" scenario. Rely on that PHAC's figures are unreliable.

Well the second wave still hasn't peaked as yet. With increased testing, changing seasons, perhaps some mental fatigue setting in (or is that just me?) I've moved the best-case figure up to 390K with the upper level unchanged.
Average 400-430K

240,263 as of 11/2 2020 with about 57 days to go.
10/7 total cases = 173,123 which equals 67140 in 26 days. Which equals 2,582 a day over those 26 days.
Extrapolating at that rate for 57 days = 147191 additional cases for a total of 387,454 cases.

3 scenarios: >50%: Peak and drop: At the lower end of the spectrum. Upping my estimate here to about 150. = 386k ~30%: Continue as-is: If the current trend continues we'll be at about 406k-ish <20%: Keep going up: This scenario could see numbers >500k

https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/documents/services/diseases-maladies/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/epidemiological-economic-research-data/update-covid-19-canada-epidemiology-modelling-20201030-eng.pdf If they keep the "maintain" scenario (p.13), Canada could hit 7,300 new cases per day at the end of December 2020, which certainly means "428,308 or more cases".
However, the increased awareness and rate of weekly tests almost doubled in the last week of October indicates the government is willing to achieve the "decrease" scenario and could facilitate to reduce the spread to 1,900 new cases per day at year's end, in an optimal case. Positivity rate is still <5% and the pandemic is driven by smaller hot spots and Provinces like Alberta (AB) and Manitoba (MB) which have skipped the first wave more or less (p.3), while Quebec (QC) seems to suppress the virus early thanks to their bad experience in the first wave.
Last day count was 2,512, so Canada is closer to the optimal scenario than to the other two worse ones.  
Thus, I maintain my forecast for the time being.
Redid my calculations using latest figures from Johns Hopkins. Current total (31/10): 237000, average new cases per day 3000, highest number 4000, latest 2374.
Surprised last bin is at 1 in 9 considering where Canada is on journey.

228,542 as of October 29, 2020 with about 61 days to go.
10/7 total cases = 173,123 which equals 55419 in 22 days. Which equals 2,519 a day over those 22 days.
Extrapolating at that rate for 61 days = 153,661 additional cases for a total of 382,203 cases.
An overly simplistic tool but the answer continues to be the same. There is no cavalry in sight.
Nice.  Canada just removed 382k tests from their rolls today.  Nice way to mess with positive % rate..... Are the # of positives even correct?
Currently about 2400/day. Times approx 60 days is 144k plus current amount 222,000 is around 366k.  Right now the trend is increasing.

Any best case must assume the second wave has peaked at around 2.6K per day: even allowing for that,  the rate of decline should be slower than that of the first wave due to increased testing, and there is the likelihood of an uptick before end of the year. 
So I can't see a total significantly under 340K, and far more chance for the peak to be higher, or rate of decline to be less dramatic. 
Overall total 340-390 ?

3 scenarios: >50%: Peak and drop: At the lower end of the spectrum. There are restrictions going into effect and/or increased and those should have an impact. What we've seen over and over again worldwide is peaks and troughs. I assume this is the most likely path: it will peak and then drop with a cumulative increase of something like 90-100k => 316k. I have trouble envisioning a scenario that leads to lower number than that. ~30%: Continue as-is: If the current trend continues we'll be at about 340k-ish (216k now + 10*2.5 + 50*2k). I think something in that neighborhood is near the high end of what's likely. <20%: Keep going up: Of course there's another possible scenario: with winter the cases continue to rise and/or just level off but don't drop back down. I'm going to give this a 5% probability. This scenario could see numbers >400k

10/23 = 211,732 cases still in the steep part of curve. That is 4923 more cases in 2 days.
10/7 total cases = 173,123 which equals 38609 in 16 days. Which equals 2,413 a day over those 16 days.
Extrapolating at that rate for 61+ 8 days = 166,501 additional cases for a total of 378,233 cases.
An overly simplistic tool but the answer continues to be the same. There is no cavalry in sight.

No change to my forecast, but just re-thinking it. 3 scenarios:  >50%: Peak and drop: At the lower end of the spectrum. There are restrictions going into effect and/or increased and those should have an impact. What we've seen over and over again worldwide is peaks and troughs. I assume this is the most likely path: it will peak and then drop with a cumulative increase of something like 60-70k => 265k. I have trouble envisioning a scenario that leads to lower number than that.  ~30%: Continue as-is: If the current trend continues we'll be at about 325k-ish (205k now + 60*2k). I think something in that neighborhood is near the high end of what's likely.  <20%: Keep going up: Of course there's another possible scenario: with winter the cases continue to rise. I'm going to give this a 5% probability. This scenario could see numbers >400k

Have to average less than 1934 cases per day from here through the remaining 69 days to fall in the second bucket, which seems very possible to me. I was expecting them to be near peak about now but it looks like that might not happen, but I still think they hit peak and start coming back down sometime before mid-november. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=daily&hideControls=true&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=location&pickerSort=asc

10/21 = 206,360 cases still in the steep part of curve. That is 4923 more cases in 2 days.
10/7 total cases = 173,123  which equals 33,237 in 2 weeks. Which equals 2,374 a day over those two weeks.
Extrapolating at that rate for 61+ 10 days = 168,559 additional cases for a total of 374,919 cases.
This is an incredibly crude tool for such a delicate question, but I don't see another path.

This is my first baseline. I started with the number of total cases as per today (206,349 on October 21) and added the current number of new cases per day (2,251), giving me a total for December 31 of 366 170. The resulting percentages were pure guesstimates. I did not do any work on distribution.

This spike appears worse than the prior. Assume holidays and quarantine fatigue will slow the decline in rates. 7-day average of 2,600 x 60 days = 156,000, plus a lower rate of 1,000 x 13 days = 13,000.
203,000
+156,000
+13,000
372,000
If Canada can flatten the curve, the 156,000 will likely decrease.
10/19 = 201,437 cases still in the steep part of curve.

Approx 70 days to go.  Current cases at 200k and av 2k cases per day slightly reducing. To get to bin 2 is 57k/70 = approx 800 cases per day
To get to bin 3 is 140k/70 = 2k cases per day
To get to bin 4 is 228k/up = 3.2k cases per day.
Going by the current trend an average of a little less than 2000 cases per day would be enough to cross the 342700 odd mark. Seems quite possible now that the trend seems upward
For a few days, until there's a foreseeable return to ~1,000 per day...

We are still on the steep part of the curve assume it bends in the next month or so. The first wave steep lasted about 2 months. Current steep incline is only a few weeks old, therefore assume steep ascent thru Nov with a knee in Dec. Testing and tracing could influence when the knee occurs, lets hope so.

Approx 15K per week currently, and I think this will increase. Testing rates are also quite high, so I see a trend towards 20K per week for a while at least.
Total 380-460K

10/14 = 189,387 cases
10/7 total cases = 173,123 which equals 16264 in a week. There are about 11 weeks to go, therefore
it could be in the range of 368,291 cases assuming some linearity (which is not realistic).

As of today, there are a total of 189,489 adding anywhere from 1,000 - 4,000 a day since October 1. With 79 days left in 2020 I came up with an additional 197,500. I do not see the number going below 1,000 on any given day between now and the end of the year heading into colder weather and the flu season causing people to stay indoors, while in turn reducing the % of social distancing. https://www.accuweather.com/en/ca/national/covid-19

10/13 = 186,881 cases
10/7 total cases = 173,123 which equals 13,758 in about a week. There are about 11 weeks to go, therefore
it could be in the range of  338,219 cases assuming some linearity (which is not realistic). However, assuming Canada can get a handle on the spread it could be in the second bucket by year end.

Current spike ongoing in Canada, 7-day average of ~2000 cases per day. Canada successfully flattened the curve after ~2-months last time. Would expect the current spike to last less time, perhaps about half of that time (30 days). So forecast 2,000 cases/day x 30 days = 50,000 - 60,000 cases through Thanksgiving. Without a spike, Canada averages ~400 per day, so an additional 400 cases/day x 45 days until the end of the year, another 18,000. Current cases: 183,000 + 55,000 + 18,000 = 256,000 exactly. Because we are entering holidays, expect a bump as family visits, thus putting Canada into the second range.

Four provinces are the primary drivers for these numbers.  I expect BC and Alberta to approximately double counts from current numbers in that time.  I expect expect Ontario and Quebec to add at least 60K between them both.  This puts the likely threshold at over 250K.  I feel that we will be past the 250K mark and I think it is unlikely we will reach the 350K mark, but there is a chance.
Reducing the highest by 13, would take a lot of cases to hit that and seems very unlikely.

Canada successfully flattened the curve earlier this year, and recently imposed additional restrictions limiting social interaction as a result of its current surge (https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/08/health/canada-coronavirus-second-wave/index.html).  Its first surge had around 40K per month until the curve was flattened.  Thus, if the last example is repeated, we should see another 110K at most by years end.  The effects of new restrictions (particularly in high population centers) won't be seen for a few more weeks.  We may find that we can rebalance back to favor Fewer than 256K.  QUESTIONS FOR RESEARCH:  Do subsequent surges in most states underperform, mimic, or previous surges.
Observed deaths have doubled but still below 10/day
10/9 = 178,117 that is 5K more in 2 days - therefore I'll bias toward the high end

daily growth is around 0.64% on average between now and may. for the next 80 days , puts between 256 - 342. but if you take fast growth of April month, daily average is 1.33% which puts above 428k. which is unlikely, government of Canada is strong at curbing, they will do whatever they can to reduce it. Ontario started shutting down indoor dining, gyms etc from yesterday again. Therefore, more likely will be between 256-428.

https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.cbc.ca/amp/1.5756516 Despite the second wave they haven't taken real measures for social distancing and are still considering them. Plus with Thanksgiving and Christmas coming up expect it to be harder to convince folks to practice social distancing

Blending a linear forecast from approx 3/4/20 to today with a "it has generally worked out worse than we expect" heuristic. Dataset here is much easier to work with (in Excel) than the one from PHAC linked above.  Numbers aren't exactly the same, but should be more than adequate for our purposes here: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/canada?country=~CAN#cumulative-confirmed-cases-how-rapidly-have-they-increased-compared-to-other-countries

My trend analysis points to +370 - currently increasing numbers.
The thing I’m not clear on is action taken by Canadian authorities. If they lock down (again) believe you end up closer to 320 - depending on nature of lockdown (I assumed similar to one started mid-March). If i understand correctly children go to school and bars remain open (yay Canada!), but you’re not supposed to socialize with anyone outside your household?  Suspect they will tighten this similar to Europe.

10/7 total cases = 173,123 
the previous wave rapid ramp lasted 2 about two months assume a similar pattern holds for this wave.
The number of cases are currently rising. https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html

First let me say another Covid question just resolved that I totally bombed on so keep that in mind when reading my reasoning. It really does not look like there is a second wave happening in Canada. The reason that I say that is because the death rate has hovered around five per day for the last two months and there is no sign of it climbing yet. I believe that this new rate of positive tests is a result of increased testing from people being tested when going back to school and possibly people being tested when going back to work after the lockdowns ended. Increased testing means increased cases, but with no increase in deaths that means we're not having a real surge. Or maybe any surge that Canada is having is happening in the younger populations such as school age.  since school age children are less vulnerable to Covid than they are to the flu with an R0 less than 1, this should not spread to the rest of the population in any major way. I would expect this increase in testing to be somewhat a temporary thing and should decline somewhat once people are in school and back to work.  Based on this reasoning I do not think the number of daily cases will rise above what it is now and in all likelihood will decline soon. I will adjust if I see daily deaths start to rise. Maybe the deaths are just delayed, but it has been long enough they should have showed up by now. This is a good page to see graphs and tends. Look at daily deaths for Canada.
https://covid19.healthdata.org/canada?view=total-deaths&tab=trend

84 days left, currently around 2000 cases a day and climbing. I would guess they peak in the next couple of weeks and then from there it's just a matter of what level they return to. 2000 cases a day would get them around 385k. 1000 a day gets to ~260k. 500 a day (a little above their late summer average) gets to ~215k. I'm guessing somewhere between 1000 a day and 2000 a day, so more weight on 256 to 342. But I'm skewing the distribution right a bit, I've been underestimating the coronavirus spread somewhat since it started so trying to avoid that. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&country=~CAN&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=daily&hideControls=true&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=location&pickerSort=asc
